Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Social and Political-Economic Dynamics of Foodways in Peri-Urban Honduras

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
University of Kentucky doctoral candidate Aeleka Schortman, under the supervision of Dr. Sarah Lyon, will undertake research on the contemporary transformation of food systems in developing countries. The agrarian transition, which is occurring throughout the world, is characterizied by movement away from local production and towards food-import dependence and industrialization. As a result, food provisioning is now less reliant on small-scale and subsistence production. Schortman will investigate the implications of these changes for individual, household, and community dynamics.

The research will be carried out in Petoa, a peri-urban, industrializing town in northern Honduras. Peri-urban areas, or satellite towns surrounding large urban centers, are key sites of agricultural and foodway change, as they are home to mixed rural and urban livelihoods and land use patterns. Nonetheless, peri-urban centers remain under-investigated in studies of foodways, which tend to focus on either rural or urban food use and production patterns. Schortman will collect data on which foods people produce, purchase, and consume; the meanings they attach to these foods and production systems; food provisioning adequacy; household histories; and household socioeconomic characteristics. She will use a mix of ethnographic research methods, including semi-interviews and informal interviews, focus groups, household case studies, and both direct and participant observation.

This research is unique in bringing together social, symbolic, political, and economic dimensions of foodways changes. It will contribute to practical and theoretical understandings of the agrarian transition in developing nations, urbanization and industrialization, and foodway change in a peri-urban locale. Supporting this research also supports the education of a social scientist.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This ethnographic, anthropological project investigates food use and acquisition amidst rapid urbanization, industrialization, and agricultural/economic change.  The study explores food and farming as a way to understand the social, economic, cultural, and personal dimensions of economic crises, rapidly shifting agro-economic systems, and neoliberal development. Set in a northern Honduran community near an industrial free trade zone (FTZ), the study speaks to issues of concern world-wide.

Honduras faces problems common in many developing nations, including: food import dependence; high/fluctuating food prices; low incomes; widespread poverty; and the inequitable distribution of land/resources. Honduras’s contemporary political-economic conditions are linked to long national/international histories of favoring elite and foreign business interests over needs of the poor. Early on, banana corporations manipulated Honduran politics, benefiting from tax breaks and land concessions. Subsequent internationally-funded development initiatives favored export agriculture and large-scale cattle ranching over domestic grain self-sufficiency; these helped consolidate land ownership amongst the rich, leaving the poor with small, poor-quality tracts to farm. Contemporary neoliberal development models also favor export-oriented production in agriculture and industry and food import dependence. Decreasing government supports (including agricultural/fuel subsidies) and forming FTZs—where foreign companies benefit from low taxes and labor costs—are part and parcel of neoliberal development. Consequently, Honduras faces growing poverty, high/fluctuating food prices, and an agrarian transition in which fewer and fewer people farm. While rapid agro-economic change is well-documented, much remains unknown about the individual, household, and community-level dynamics of such changes; the social, symbolic, cultural, and personal dimensions of food systems and economies in flux remain under-investigated.

This ethnographic—survey, interview, and observation based—research addresses this knowledge gap. Surveys offer quantitative data on: food use/consumption/purchase; the economics of food sales and production; household composition and incomes; demographic variables, etc. Observations and interviews provide qualitative information on: personal/household decisions; food-related behaviors, beliefs, and values; the daily work of food acquisition, preparation, production, and sales; and individuals’/households’ struggles and successes. Multiple methods shed light on important topics in academia, politics, and policy-making.  Qualitative analysis explores the hopes, dreams, perceptions, struggles, and anxieties implicated in rapid agro-economic change; it addresses the subjective, personal dimensions of neoliberal policies. Quantitative data permit a detailed economic analysis of food-related practices, household income-generating strategies, and rapidly changing benefits/drawbacks of farming and or/factory work, amongst other factors. 

Specifically, analysis will demonstrate how neoliberal policies fail to provide promised development. The duty-free importation of foreign foods—e.g., US government-subsidized grains—means unsubsidized, small-scale Honduran farmers are easily out-competed by foreign producers.
